para.paratext: A subpoena ad testificandum is a judicial writ issued in the name of the court commanding a witness to appear and give testimony at a specific time and place.[1] A subpoena duces tecum requires a witness to appear in court to bring a document or piece of evidence to be inspected by the court.[2] O.C.G.A. § 24-13-21 addresses both.

Any party is entitled to subpoena an in-state witness. In past practice, Georgia attorneys secured signed and sealed subpoenas from the clerk of court which left blank the name and address of the proposed witness. Under the revised Code § 24-13-21(d), attorneys may issue subpoenas as officers of the court without obtaining a signed subpoena from the clerk of court.[3]
Federal court administrators provide a standard form to attorneys seeking subpoena issuance. In Georgia, contact the local clerk of court to obtain the proper form.[4]

Under O.C.G.A. § 24-13-26, the court will not grant a continuance based on failure of a witness to appear unless the requesting party notifies the clerk of the witness' name and address at least six hours before his appearance is required, and the subpoena was served at least 24 hours prior to the time of the required appearance.

With the Georgia General Assembly's passage of the Uniform Interstate Depositions and Discovery Act (UIDDA),[5] Georgia joined a growing number of states which allow a party to submit a foreign subpoena to the clerk of court where the discovery is located if the state in which discovery is sought has adopted UIDDA.[6]

Under the Uniform Interstate Depositions and Discovery Act, O.C.G.A. § 24-13-111, a witness can be compelled by subpoena issued by the clerk of the superior court where the witness resides. The Georgia legislature revised the definition of “subpoena” to include a document issued under authority of a court of record requiring a person to:
Attend and give testimony at a deposition;
Produce and permit inspection and copying of designated books, documents, records, electronically stored information, or tangible things in the possession, custody, or control of such person; or
Permit inspection of premises under the control of such person.[7]
Under this section, a party may issue a subpoena for documents alone without deposing a party unless a party's deposition is needed for authentication purposes.

If the foreign state has not adopted UIDDA, then under Georgia's Uniform Interstate Depositions and Discovery Act, O.C.G.A. § 24-13-113, a party may apply for subpoenas that require a person to attend and give testimony at a deposition. The clerk of the county where the witness resides must issue the subpoena. The Uniform Interstate Depositions and Discovery Act applies only to civil proceedings.[8]

This conforms to Fed. R. Civ. P. 45.
